node.title: Bankers expect to see a bump in their bonuses.
node.description: Wall Street firms are likely to pay up to keep their top performers from leaving.

node.title: Amazon agrees to pay $500,000 in California over claims that it hid Covid-19 cases from workers.
node.description: The judgment, which is subject to court approval, is in line with a “right to know” law that was designed to keep workers safe in the pandemic.

node.title: Kim Kardashian Outlines 'Cold Machinery' of Death Penalty Ahead of Julius Jones Execution
node.description: The reality television star said she and other advocates were "anxiously awaiting" Oklahoma governor's decision on whether to commute Jones' death sentence.

node.title: Hundreds stung after storms wash scorpions into people's homes
node.description: The storms forced scorpions from their hiding places into many houses across the province.

node.title: U.S.-China Summit Produces Little More Than Polite Words, but They Help
node.description: In a chilly relationship of mutual mistrust, staving off the prospect of a broader conflict between two superpowers counts as progress.

node.title: Who’s to Blame for Rising Prices
node.description: Why do so many things seem to cost more now?

node.title: Labor announces NBN pitch ahead of next federal election
node.description: The federal opposition promises to give 1.5 million homes and businesses access to higher speed internet if Labor wins the next federal election.

node.title: Belarus-Poland border row fuels fear of new migrant crisis in Germany
node.description: Germans have been on edge about immigration since the controversial admission of 1 million refugees in 2015. Now an EU faceoff with Belarus' Russian-backed autocrat is driving a new influx.

node.title: Ryan Sets Course for Showdown at Jonestown 'Prison'
node.description: Leo Ryan is less than impressed with the People's Temple in Georgetown; meanwhile, Jim Jones talks about death.

node.title: Jailed former Ipswich mayor says he pleaded guilty against advice of lawyers because he 'just wanted it all over with'
node.description: Jailed former Ipswich mayor Paul Pisasale says he went against advice and "didn't want to" fight allegations of corruption, while giving evidence as a witness in a hearing today.

node.title: Uganda rocked by two explosions, killing two people, injuring 24 in Kampala
node.description: Local television station NTV Uganda reports two explosions — one very close to parliament and one near the central police station — with four people critically injured.

node.title: Teacher With COVID Dies Weeks After Husband Sued Hospital Over Ivermectin Refusal
node.description: Tamara Drock, who was admitted to the hospital with COVID, had been placed on a ventilator in September when her condition worsened.

node.title: 'Wait and see': Anxious Forbes residents watch floodwaters rise
node.description: After days of preparations and evacuations, the community of Forbes in the central west is awaiting a likely 10.65 metre flood peak.

node.title: The Indy Ski Pass Lives Up to Its Name
node.description: The lower-cost pass targets skiers who like to stay local and sample smaller, independently owned mountains, while saving money.

node.title: How to Ski Smarter in the Age of Multi-Mountain Passes
node.description: Resort companies’ focus on season passes has changed skiing, but savvy skiers can dodge the crowds and reap the benefits.

node.title: The Police Fatally Shot a Young Girl. Two Teenagers Are Charged With Murder.
node.description: After two teenage boys exchanged gunfire outside a football game in a Philadelphia suburb, the police opened fire and killed an 8-year-old girl. Now the teenagers are charged with a crime.

node.title: Kyle Rittenhouse Verdict: Fate of Kenosha Shooter Hinges on This Question
node.description: The jury in the divisive trial must ask whether they agree that the 18-year-old was acting in self-defense when he killed Joseph Rosenbaum and Anthony Huber.

node.title: 'We feel safe now': Perth family tells of their relief after five days stranded in Simpson Desert
node.description: A young Perth family who had to be rescued from the Simpson Desert after their campervan became bogged have spoken to the ABC about their experience.

node.title: A Colleague Had Covid. Should Our Supervisor Have Told Us?
node.description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on balancing safety and medical-privacy concerns in the workplace — and how best to persuade a friend to get vaccinated.

node.title: How I Became Obsessed With Accidental Time Travel
node.description: The web is awash with ordinary peoples’ stories of “time slips.” Their real magic is what they can tell us about our relationship to time.

node.title: How to Spot a Shooting Star
node.description: You don’t need fancy equipment. Check the weather.

node.title: Jane Campion Is Taking Cinema to the Darkest Human Places
node.description: In “The Power of the Dog,” her first movie in 12 years, the filmmaker ventures into the American West — and the inner worlds of cruel, complicated men.

node.title: Theirs Is a ‘Traditional Untraditional’ Union
node.description: The Tony Award-winning actor Daisy Eagan and her husband Keith Bloom, who are in an open relationship, share how they designed a marriage that works for them.

node.title: In Florida, a Gut Renovation in Shades of Grape
node.description: The overwrought moldings in their neo-Classical home had begun to feel stuffy, so they redid the whole thing — with an emphasis on food and wine.

node.title: In Another Trump Book, a Journalist’s Belated Awareness Steals the Show
node.description: “Betrayal,” by Jonathan Karl, is a record of Trump’s last year in office — and of a seasoned White House correspondent’s attempt to understand it.

node.title: A Debut Novel Where Small Moments Add Up to Something Big
node.description: In “A Little Hope,” Ethan Joella explores quiet lives in small-town Connecticut.

node.title: How the Greek Revolution of 1821 Led to the Global System of Nation-States
node.description: Mark Mazower’s “The Greek Revolution” examines a century-old event that continues to reverberate today.

node.title: Bildungsromans From Around the World
node.description: New fiction by Elif Shafak, S.J. Sindu and Bisi Adjapon.

node.title: Seven Immigrant Women Who Changed the Way Americans Eat
node.description: “Taste Makers,” by Mayukh Sen, features women who, often while confronting sexism and racism in the food industry, introduced Americans to the dishes of their native cultures.

node.title: The Cutting Mind and Romantic Heart of Elizabeth Hardwick
node.description: “A Splendid Intelligence,” by Cathy Curtis, is the first biography of the much admired critic and novelist.

node.title: The True-Life Inspiration for Dostoyevsky’s Famous Murderer
node.description: The model for Raskolnikov, the tortured killer in the Russian author’s masterpiece “Crime and Punishment,” was a Frenchman who committed a double murder, Kevin Birmingham writes in “The Sinner and the Saint,” his portrait of Dostoyevsky and the making of the novel.

node.title: Neal Stephenson’s Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World
node.description: “Termination Shock,” his latest novel, is set in a future gone haywire from the impacts of climate disaster.

node.title: Latin Grammys 2021: Complete Nominees List
node.description: Here are the nominees for the 22nd annual ceremony.

node.title: Jeanna de Waal Has Already Forgotten About That ‘Diana’ Film
node.description: The Netflix version of Broadway’s “Diana, the Musical” landed with a thud. But it got people talking. Now the show’s lead actress is staying positive ahead of opening night.

node.title: Skiing Hut-to-Hut in the Maine Wilderness
node.description: An effort to conserve the state’s 100 Mile Wilderness has created one of the best lodge-to-lodge cross-country ski routes in the United States.

node.title: 9 Wintry Wonderlands for New Cross-Country Skiers
node.description: Here’s a sampling of centers that offer a seamless introduction to cross-country skiing, with lessons, meticulously groomed trails and other activities nearby.

node.title: Does it Matter if I Eat the Stickers on Fruits and Vegetables?
node.description: They won’t cause you any harm, but there are reasons to remove them before taking a bite.

node.title: How Far-Right Extremism Invaded Mainstream Politics
node.description: A historian of the white power movement discusses Jan. 6, Tucker Carlson and the threat of politically motivated violence.

node.title: Democratic Socialists Need to Take a Hard Look in the Mirror
node.description: Our beliefs just might not be as popular as we like to think they are.

node.title: A Rare Look at Israeli Soldiers in the West Bank City of Hebron
node.description: Six former soldiers share their accounts.

node.title: The Worst of Both Worlds: Zooming From the Office
node.description: Work life for many is in a mushy middle ground, and what’s at stake isn’t just who is getting talked over in meetings. It’s whether flexibility is sustainable, even with all the benefits it confers.

node.title: Before Buying Lift Tickets, Get Your Skis
node.description: Rising demand and supply shortages suggest you rent or buy before the snow flies.

node.title: What to Expect as Ski Areas Head Into Another Pandemic Season
node.description: With fewer Covid protocols at many resorts, guests can expect shorter lift lines and less outdoor masking. But policies differ, depending on the area, so know before you go.

node.title: Ghislaine Maxwell, Epstein’s Companion, Finally Goes on Trial
node.description: Jury selection is set to begin on Tuesday following a flurry of motions that began to bring the scope of the hotly anticipated trial into focus.

node.title: Racial Equity in Infrastructure, a U.S. Goal, Is Left to States
node.description: The decision about how to spend the money falls largely to state governments, raising questions about whether the package can live up to its ambition.

node.title: 2 Explosions Hit Ugandan Capital
node.description: Witnesses said there was a blast near a police station and another near Parliament. At least 24 people have been hospitalized.

node.title: In Moscow’s Technological Advances, a ‘Double-Edged Sword’
node.description: The latest example is Face Pay, which replaces a Metro card with facial recognition. It may be advanced, but activists are sounding the alarm on privacy issues.

node.title: U.S. Allies Drive Much of World’s Democratic Decline, Data Shows
node.description: Washington-aligned countries backslid at nearly double the rate of non-allies, data shows, complicating long-held assumptions about American influence.

node.title: A Veteran Diplomat, a ‘Tragic Figure,’ Battles Critics in the U.S. and Afghanistan
node.description: Zalmay Khalilzad, who stepped down as the envoy for Afghanistan after the U.S. exit, has defended the deal he negotiated with the Taliban during the Trump administration.

node.title: Cities Are Not Only Tackling Covid, But Its Pollution, Too
node.description: All around the world the remnants of a global pandemic are testing the resolve of governments and private firms to rid the planet of its waste.

node.title: Will an Island in Indonesia Become a New Frontier in the Space Race?
node.description: An Indigenous clan fears it will lose its place in the world as the government pursues a quest to open a spaceport and lure the billionaire SpaceX founder Elon Musk.

node.title: Boy Scout Helps Rescue Injured Dog and Owners Lost on Hawaii Hiking Trail
node.description: 12-year-old David King helped carry Smokey, a 100lb pitbull whose paws were bleeding, to safety on the Waimano Trail.

node.title: TikTok Class Action Lawsuit: Who's Eligible & How To File a Payment Claim
node.description: TikTok users across the country have been receiving a notification informing them that they might be eligible to claim a settlement payment from a recent lawsuit.

node.title: How Much Space Debris Is There? Russian Anti-Satellite Test Creates 1,500 Pieces of Junk
node.description: The missile target is believed to have been a Russian satellite destroyed in the explosion. It highlighted the risk of space junk to missions like the ISS.

node.title: Rigged Voting Machines? Chinese Hacking? Local Fraud? Officials Kept Digging
node.description: In this daily series, Newsweek explores the steps that led to the January 6 Capitol Riot.

node.title: Property developer's art collection sells for $921m, including highest price paid for Pollock
node.description: The art collection belonging to Harry Macklowe and ex-wife Linda Burg goes under the hammer, after a New York judge ordered them to sell it after their divorce and split the profits 50/50.

node.title: Jury to decide if incident that left woman horribly burned was attempted murder or accident
node.description: After seven weeks of hearing evidence in the Hobart Supreme Court, the jury will now decide whether an incident in Hobart's north in 2017 — leaving a woman with severe burns to her body — was an attempted murder or an accident.

node.title: Jen Psaki's 'Sheriff Joe' Remarks Leave Internet Confused
node.description: Biden was reportedly called 'Sheriff Joe' when he served as vice president and oversaw stimulus spending.

node.title: Biden's 3.5-hour summit with Xi focuses on "managing strategic risks"
node.description: The wide-ranging discussion between the U.S. and Chinese leaders brought no major breakthroughs, but a "respectful" debate on contentious issues including Taiwan and human rights.

node.title: The Housing Crisis in the Bronx, Made Worse by the Pandemic
node.description: In a borough where unemployment is almost three times the national rate, thousands of renters are now threatened with eviction as state pandemic aid dwindles.

node.title: Watch: 250lb Florida Bear Had Plastic Container Stuck on Her Head for 28 Days
node.description: The bear is believed to have become trapped after sticking her head in an automatic pet feeder.

node.title: Nick Kyrgios backtracks on call to cancel Australian Open
node.description: Kyrgios claims he was taken out of context when he said he didn't think the season-opening major should go ahead, as he believes it's not "morally right" to allow unvaccinated players to enter Australia.

node.title: Grazier with truckload of sheep forced to lie to autistic son after shock border denial
node.description: Wes Herring says his boy, 10, "busted his rear end" helping him get their livestock ready for the trip. But despite being assured their path was clear, they were turned back, 360km from home.

node.title: 'A perfect storm': Why COVID-19 is infiltrating Indigenous communities
node.description: The COVID-19 outbreak among the Indigenous population in Moree, in regional NSW, leaves Queensland watching with trepidation.

node.title: 'The maths does not add up': NT hospital boss warns staff of bed shortages as COVID outbreak worsens
node.description: In a scathing letter to staff, the executive director of the NT's largest hospital has announced all non-urgent surgeries this week will be postponed and visitors banned from the facilities.

node.title: Puppies kept inside pet stores throughout lockdown
node.description: An online petition is calling for the end of pets for sale in shops following backlash against an Auckland shop that kept two puppies in-store throughout lockdown. Audio

node.title: 'Insulting': Te Arawa rep leaves meeting over governance model proposal
node.description: A Te Arawa representative says it is "insulting" and a "farce" the council did not consult with iwi about a proposed new governance structure.

node.title: U.S.-China trade was expected to be a central issue.
node.description: By Keith Bradsher

node.title: The summit was virtual, but the locations carefully chosen.
node.description: Each leader took the call in a room freighted with symbolic weight, as diplomatic protocol persists even in the coronavirus era.

node.title: How the Pandemic Worsened a Housing Crisis in the Bronx
node.description: In a New York City borough where residents have long struggled to afford their homes, thousands are now threatened with eviction as state pandemic aid dwindles.

node.title: What’s the Future of Outdoor Dining in New York?
node.description: As the city debates a plan to make outdoor dining permanent, vocal opposition is growing in affluent, restaurant-rich neighborhoods like the West Village.

node.title: Joe Biden and Xi Jinping Cool Flaring U.S.-China Tensions in First Summit
node.description: The leaders, meeting virtually face-to-face for the first time this year, reaffirmed their respective positions during the summit focused on averting conflict.

node.title: Two global superpowers, one Zoom call and four hours: Did the Biden-Xi summit avert catastrophe?
node.description: Tensions between the US and China are simmering. But one of the few areas Joe Biden and Xi Jinping agree on is that letting relations deteriorate further would be a mistake of historic proportions, writes Kathryn Diss.

node.title: Pete Sampras reveals who he thinks is the greatest of all time in men's tennis
node.description: The debate over who is the 'GOAT' in men's tennis has divided opinions for years, but 14-time major winner Sampras has no doubt that Novak Djokovic is the one.

node.title: NASA is outraged by an anti-satellite missile test. Russia's downplaying the whole thing
node.description: The head of Russia's space agency is due to meet with NASA representatives over the incident, which put International Space Station astronauts on alert.

node.title: Seth Meyers: Steve Bannon Fancies Himself to Be Logan Roy
node.description: Meyers said Bannon was more like “a coked-up flunky who would get hired to help cousin Greg shred some documents and accidentally screw it up.”

node.title: Russia has been building its military on the Ukraine border, raising fears of another conflict in Europe
node.description: Fears of a Russian military attack on neighbouring Ukraine are growing amongst the international community, as the Kremlin continues its build-up of troops on the border.

node.title: Potential corruption risks in draft legislation for 2032 Olympic Games organising committee, CCC warns
node.description: Provisions to exempt elected officials from declaring conflicts of interest if they are also a director on the 2032 Olympic Games organising committee presents corruption risks, the head of Queensland's corruption watchdog warns.

node.title: Cabinet never considered prioritising South Auckland vaccines, documents reveal
node.description: Public health experts have expressed disappointment after discovering the government didn't discuss their advice to prioritise vaccination efforts in the area.

node.title: After her fiancé was killed by a train, Maddie is determined to improve rail crossing safety
node.description: Maddie and Ethan were due to marry in March and looked forward to starting a family. But in February, Ethan was killed at a rail crossing which had no lights or boom gates.

node.title: 'A serious escalation' in the NT's COVID situation has sparked lockdowns and mask mandates. Here's what we know
node.description: Katherine has been in and out of lockdown for two weeks, and now the remote Robinson River community is too. So how did it get to the point in the NT and what do we know about the latest COVID cluster?

node.title: Oxford criminologist 'outraged' by NZ women’s prisons
node.description: An expert on America's 'supermax' jails says the way women are treated in New Zealand prisons is "extremely troubling".

node.title: 'Callous and irresponsible' - Air NZ cancellations strand workers in Cook Islands
node.description: A recruitment firm bringing Filipino workers from the Cook Islands says Air New Zealand gave travellers a shock when the flight schedule was wiped.

node.title: Ex-fugitive paedophile sentenced to nine years in jail for child sex abuse after decade on the run
node.description: Former Broome tour operator and international fugitive Charles Batham is handed a nine-year prison term for abusing two girls in WA's Kimberley, after fleeing Australia a decade ago.

node.title: Social distancing, PPE not used until first case emerged during Australia's deadliest aged care COVID-19 outbreak
node.description: A coronial inquest into the outbreak at St Basil's in Melbourne's north that led to the deaths of 50 people has heard a staff member who spread COVID to the facility was permitted to come to work after reporting flu-like symptoms.

node.title: Colin Craig's former employee awarded $400,000
node.description: Rachel MacGregor has been awarded $400,000 in damages by the High Court after she was defamed by her former employer, one-time Conservative Party leader Colin Craig.

node.title: Ernie Dingo joins vaccination fight in bid to boost jab rates in WA Indigenous communities
node.description: TV personality Ernie Dingo will drive from Perth to the Pilbara this week as part of a federal government campaign to boost vaccination rates among Indigenous communities in remote WA.

node.title: 'Best present I've ever asked for': Families reunite at airports as COVID-19 rules ease in Queensland
node.description: Elated families reunite across Queensland's airports today as COVID-19 restrictions ease in the state, but there are others waiting to drive across the border still locked out and at the "end of their tether".

node.title: 'Extreme body modification artist' guilty of manslaughter after botched implant surgery
node.description: Self-proclaimed extreme body modification artist Brendan Russell is found guilty of manslaughter over the death of a NSW woman he discouraged from seeking medical help for an infected implant.

node.title: Child hit by vehivle in Papakura
node.description: A child has been taken to hospital in critical condition after being hit by a vehicle in south Auckland.

node.title: Live updates: 40% of early childhood centres expect to lose teachers
node.description: The Early Childhood Council says 40 percent of its members expected to lose unvaccinated teachers today.

node.title: Rescuers unable to save drowning victim at Bethells Beach
node.description: Rescuers were unable to save a person who has drowned at Te Henga Bethells Beach in Auckland this afternoon.

node.title: Wyoming GOP votes to no longer recognize Liz Cheney
node.description: This is the second action the Wyoming Republican party has taken against Cheney.

node.title: Elon Musk Sells $150+M in Tesla Stock Options, Shares, SEC Documents Show
node.description: The sale comes days after Senator Bernie Sanders stated that Musk should "pay his fair share."

node.title: Investore reports first half-year profit of $56.9m
node.description: Investore's first half-year profit is down more than a third as gains in the value of its portfolio of big box retail properties slowed.

node.title: Southern DHB prepares for fewer home visits as vaccine mandate impacts staffing
node.description: The Southern DHB says essential home and community support services will be prioritised as it prepares for months with lower staffing levels in the wake of the vaccine mandate.

node.title: Cyber threats continue to increase in New Zealand, new report finds
node.description: A new report has found cyber threats are continuing to grow in New Zealand, as attacks become more sophisticated.

node.title: Bishop condemns 'ignorant, divisive' anti-vax parishioners peddling myths
node.description: The head of the Catholic diocese in Cairns says he has never before encountered such "dangerous and soul destroying" ignorance in almost 30 years in the job.

node.title: Biden says superpowers must 'not veer into conflict' as virtual summit with Xi opens
node.description: While the two leaders began their talks with friendly waves, they are meeting at a time of mounting tensions in the US-China relationship.

node.title: Māori businesses confident, but continue to face barriers - report
node.description: Māori businesses are overwhelmingly confident about the future, but financial literacy and lack of resources remain barriers to achieving their goals, according to a new report.
